study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exercise-based interventions, including aquatic exercise, on pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory biomarkers in fibromyalgia patients and identify the most effective type and modality.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise showed better improvements in reducing pro-inflammatory biomarkers compared to resistance exercise, with significant decreases in IL8. However, no significant increase in anti-inflammatory biomarkers (IL10) was observed.
population_specificity: Patients with fibromyalgia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of water-based versus land-based perturbation balance training in elderly individuals with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The water-based perturbation exercise group showed significant reductions in pain, fear-avoidance behaviors, and improvements in fall efficacy and straight leg raise compared to the land-based group. Both groups improved in clinical outcomes, except for fear-avoidance beliefs related to physical activity in the land-based group.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (mean age ~63 years) with chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of water-based exercise (WE) in improving functional capacity and respiratory muscle strength in patients with COPD.
results_summary: The study found that water-based exercise improves functional capacity compared to a non-exercising control group, with significant improvements in lung function, respiratory muscle strength, and maximal or aerobic exercise.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically analyze the efficacy of aquatic exercise on pain intensity, disability, and quality of life among adults with low back pain.
results_summary: Pooled results showed that aquatic exercises significantly reduced pain and disability while improving quality of life in adults with low back pain. The study concluded that aquatic exercise regimens were effective for this population.
population_specificity: Adults with low back pain

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between aquatic exercise and improvements in brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) levels, a marker of cognitive function, in older women.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise showed a significant association with improved BDNF levels, though the sample size for this specific regimen was small. The overall analysis indicated moderate improvement in BDNF levels across all exercise regimens studied.
population_specificity: Older women (with a noted limitation of 10.3% male inclusion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the benefits and mechanisms of exercise interventions, including aquatic exercise, in pulmonary rehabilitation for patients with chronic respiratory diseases.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise was found to effectively improve exercise capacity, physical fitness, and pulmonary function in patients with chronic respiratory diseases by enhancing immune response, controlling inflammation, and improving gas exchange.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic respiratory diseases (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bronchial asthma, bronchiectasis, interstitial lung disease, and lung cancer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of aquatic therapeutic exercise in improving fatigue, pain, lymphedema, and quality of life in female breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise was effective in reducing fatigue (2 studies), pain (3 studies), and improving quality of life (4 studies), but effects on lymphedema were inconsistent. High adherence and no adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Female breast cancer survivors

study_goal: To determine if a 12-week aqua-plyometric exercise program improves muscle strength, bone mineral properties, and physical fitness in juvenile idiopathic arthritis patients.
results_summary: The AquaPlyo group showed significant improvements in quadriceps peak torque, bone mineral density (areal and volumetric), bone mineral content, BMD Z score, and physical fitness compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 48 patients (aged 12-18 years) with polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

study_goal: To examine the efficacy and safety of aquatic exercise for people with knee osteoarthritis compared to no exercise and land-based exercise.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise significantly improved pain, stiffness, and physical function compared to no exercise, with sustained pain relief at three months postintervention. No significant differences were found between aquatic and land-based exercise for these outcomes, and no serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: People with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review methods for monitoring aquatic exercise using wearable devices and identify gaps in current research.
results_summary: The review identified 23 studies using wearables for underwater motion analysis, highlighting four research gaps: lack of clinical protocols, deficit of whole-body studies, absence of longitudinal studies, and reliance on land-based methods. The study advocates for technological and methodological improvements in underwater motion analysis.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if aquatic exercise improves reactive balance more effectively than land exercise in older adults.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that aquatic exercise will lead to better outcomes in reactive balance tasks compared to land exercise, but results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65 years or above.
effective_dosage: Single bout intervention including a ball throwing and catching task.
study_duration: Single bout intervention with follow-up assessments immediately after and one week post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of aquatic exercises to land-based exercises for managing chronic pain and pain-related outcomes.
results_summary: Aquatic exercises were found to have similar efficacy to land-based exercises for pain-related outcomes. The abstract also highlights the effectiveness of multidisciplinary care and occupational therapy, though limited evidence exists for some interventions like taping and orthoses.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic pain, including those with knee arthritis who are overweight or obese.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for spa rehabilitative interventions (including aquatic exercise) in improving motor function, symptoms, quality of life, and cost-effectiveness for patients with neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: The selected studies showed statistically significant improvements in motor function, balance, quality of life, and psychological well-being for Parkinson's disease patients after thermal rehabilitative treatments, with cost-effectiveness noted. However, the literature remains limited.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of aquatic physical therapy on clinical symptoms, physical function, and quality of life in patients with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: Aquatic physical therapy showed significant benefits compared to other exercises or no exercise, improving pain (measured by visual analogue scale), physical function, and quality of life in fibromyalgia patients. The meta-analysis included 14 randomized controlled trials with 762 patients.
population_specificity: Patients with fibromyalgia syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of long-term aquatic exercise training on balance, fatigue, and motor function through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Aquatic therapy had a positive effect on fatigue compared to the control group, as measured by the Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) in physical outcomes. The meta-analysis included 16 trials with 794 participants, showing statistically significant improvements.
population_specificity: 794 participants across 16 trials (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of water-based exercise on pain, limb motor function, quality of life, and limb volume in patients with primary and secondary upper and lower limb lymphedema.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise improved shoulder range of motion, limb strength, pain perception, and quality of life, with some studies reporting reduced limb volume, especially short-term. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with primary or secondary upper or lower limb lymphedema, mostly breast cancer-related.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of Deep Water Running (DWR) on cardiorespiratory fitness, physical function, and quality of life in healthy and clinical populations.
results_summary: DWR showed similar effects on cardiorespiratory fitness compared to land-based training, with limited data on physical function and quality of life. The aquatic environment may offer advantages for high-intensity exercise in weak, injured, or pain-affected populations, but more studies are needed.
population_specificity: Healthy and clinical populations (weak, injured, or in pain).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of aquatic exercise in improving proprioception in individuals with chronic ankle instability (CAI) compared to other exercise therapies.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise had a relatively low efficacy (SUCRA=47.8%) in improving joint position sense in individuals with CAI, ranking below foot and ankle muscle strengthening, static balance exercise, and corrective exercise.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic ankle instability (CAI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 16 weeks of aerobic training versus 8 weeks of aerobic followed by 8 weeks of combined training on the quality of life (QoL) of older women exercising in an aquatic environment.
results_summary: QoL improved significantly in the training groups after the 16-week intervention, with no change in the control group. Combined training (resistance and aerobic) provided additional benefits to autonomy, environment, and past, present, and future activities domains compared to aerobic-only training.
population_specificity: 52 older women
effective_dosage: Aerobic training at heart rate percentage associated with anaerobic threshold; resistance training sets at maximal effort (specific frequency not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of combining photobiomodulation therapy (PBM) with aquatic exercise (deep water running) on pain intensity, disability, physical performance (6WTA), and biomarkers (cortisol and CK levels) in individuals with chronic non-specific low back pain (NSCLBP).
results_summary: The study assessed the combined effects of PBM and aquatic exercise on pain, disability, physical performance, and biomarker levels in NSCLBP patients, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic non-specific low back pain (NSCLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on aquatic therapy (AT) for persons with neuromuscular diseases (NMD) to assess its current state and identify gaps for future clinical studies.
results_summary: The review analyzed 28 articles, most focusing on myopathies, and found a growing number of studies over time. However, heterogeneity in AT interventions highlighted the need for standardized parameters to better interpret results.
population_specificity: Persons with neuromuscular diseases (NMD), particularly myopathies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the benefits of aquatic exercise (AE) and land-based exercise (LBE) on pain, functionality, and quality of life after arthroscopic partial meniscectomy (APM).
results_summary: Both AE and LBE significantly improved pain, function, isokinetic muscle strength, and quality of life in patients after APM, with no significant differences between the two groups. AE showed broader improvements in peak torque values at different angular velocities compared to LBE.
population_specificity: Middle-aged (35-50), physically active patients who underwent APM for a degenerative meniscal tear.
effective_dosage: 1-hour sessions per day, three days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aquatic exercise programs improve quality of life, physical function, and psychological well-being in patients with neurological disorders.
results_summary: The study found that aquatic exercise improved balance, gait, and reduced pain, leading to enhanced quality of life through better physical health, mental health, and vitality.
population_specificity: Patients with neurological disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different exercise therapies, including aquatic exercise, in reducing fatigue in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise was ranked as the most effective intervention for reducing multiple sclerosis-related fatigue, outperforming other exercise types and controls. Aerobic exercise showed small-to-moderate effects, while climbing was the only intervention worse than controls.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (1,470 participants across 27 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness and safety of moderate aquatic aerobic exercise during pregnancy on epidural analgesia use, labor pain, delivery outcomes, and maternal/newborn safety.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise did not reduce epidural use or affect delivery type but reduced labor pain perception. The intervention showed no significant differences in adverse events between groups.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (14 to 20 weeks' gestation) with low risk of complications.
effective_dosage: Moderate aquatic aerobic exercise (specific frequency/intensity not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on aquatic exercise for health promotion using bibliometric methods and identify research trends and hot spots.
results_summary: The study found that aquatic exercise research is expanding, with a focus on cardiovascular health in clinical populations such as stroke, obesity, and hypertension. The most cited references covered physiology, biochemistry, physical fitness, and psychological health.
population_specificity: Clinical populations (e.g., stroke, overweight, hypertension, heart failure) and general health promotion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of non-pharmacological conservative therapies, including aquatic exercise, on pain intensity, disability, and physical function in fibromyalgia patients.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise improved pain intensity, disability, and physical function in fibromyalgia patients in the short term, with strong evidence supporting its efficacy.
population_specificity: Adults with fibromyalgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if preoperative aquatic exercise could improve postoperative outcomes in elderly patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty by enhancing preoperative physical function.
results_summary: The aquatic exercise intervention (AEI) was associated with improved functional outcomes (WOMAC scores, chair-stand, MAT-sf), reduced depression, and better cognition, though it did not significantly affect complications, ER visits, or disposition to nursing homes/rehab facilities.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age 67.1) scheduled for elective total knee arthroplasty, scoring at or below the 50th percentile in mobility assessment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of water-based exercise versus land-based exercise on physical health and quality of life in older adults before, after, and one year following a 10-week intervention.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise showed greater improvements in physical health (timed up-and-go test, hip muscle strength) and quality of life (SF-36) compared to land-based exercise, with no significant differences in other fitness or falls-efficacy measures.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65 years and older.
effective_dosage: Not specified (10-week exercise program, frequency not detailed).
study_duration: 10 weeks (with assessments at pre-, post-, and 1-year follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aquatic exercises on lung function and weight loss in obese children compared to exergames and a control group.
results_summary: The study found that aquatic aerobic exercise, performed three times per week, led to significant improvements in anthropometric variables (e.g., body weight reduction) in obese children, though specific lung function results were not detailed in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: Obese male primary-school children (n=61).
effective_dosage: Three 60-minute sessions per week, consisting of warm-up, main exercises, and cool down.
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated in the abstract (follow-up was one month post-intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether adding deep-water running (DWR) to aquatic exercise (AQE) improved disability, pain intensity, and functional capacity in patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP) compared to AQE alone.
results_summary: The study found that DWR significantly reduced pain compared to AQE alone, but no significant differences were observed for disability or functional capacity. The effect size for pain reduction was moderate (d‾ = 0.80).
population_specificity: Adult patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of aquatic exercises (AE) versus land exercises (LE) on improving dynamic balance in older adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that AE and LE had comparable effects on dynamic steady-state balance, proactive balance, and balance test batteries, suggesting AE is a viable alternative to LE for improving dynamic balance in older adults.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aquatic exercise training improves sexual function in females with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that aquatic exercise had significant positive effects on overall sexual function scores (p < .001), suggesting potential benefits for female PwMS, though further large-scale studies are needed for confirmation.
population_specificity: 60 married females with MS (mean age: 37.68 years; median EDSS: 1.75).
effective_dosage: Aquatic exercise twice a week (2x/w) or three times a week (3x/w).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the qualitative and quantitative results of aquatic physical therapy treatments for individuals with Multiple Sclerosis through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found that aquatic physical therapy is a valid rehabilitation method for Multiple Sclerosis, with most quantitative results being statistically significant. However, more studies with larger participant numbers and follow-up periods are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Individuals with Multiple Sclerosis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of aquatic exercise on sleep quality and inflammatory biomarkers (IL-1β and TNF-α) in children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD).
results_summary: Aquatic exercise improved sleep quality and reduced serum levels of IL-1β and TNF-α in children with ASD compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 40 boys with ASD, aged 6-14.
effective_dosage: 2 sessions per week, 60 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and compare outcome measures used in aquatic physiotherapy for children with neuromuscular and neurodevelopmental disorders, using the ICF framework.
results_summary: The study identified four outcome measures (HAAR, Conatser, WOTA 1 and 2, and SWIM) linked to 35 ICF categories, with most items assessing activity and participation. Content diversity was low (<0.5), and while measures showed theoretical homogeneity, differences were found in content analysis.
population_specificity: Children with neuromuscular and neurodevelopmental disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify exercise intervention principles that improve physical function, weight management, or musculoskeletal pain relief in young and middle-aged adults with obesity, and propose an evidence-based exercise prescription for secondary osteoarthritis prevention.
results_summary: The study found that moderate-intensity exercise (40-80% VO₂ max) for 30-60 minutes, three times per week, was effective for weight management and reducing obesity-related musculoskeletal symptoms. Common principles in exercise prescription led to improvements in physical function and pain relief.
population_specificity: Young and middle-aged adults (18-50 years) with obesity, excluding those with peri-menopausal status, cancer, or obesity-related comorbidities.
effective_dosage: 30-60 minutes, three times per week at moderate intensity (40-80% VO₂ max).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of water therapy for disease activity, functional capacity, spinal mobility, and pain in patients with ankylosing spondylitis.
results_summary: Water therapy reduced disease activity and pain in patients with ankylosing spondylitis but did not improve functional capacity or spinal mobility. The analgesic effect was noted both during and after treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with ankylosing spondylitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and recommendation level of aquatic exercise as a treatment for knee osteoarthritis (OA) based on meta-analytic data and expert consensus.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise was classified as a Level 1B/Level 2 treatment for knee OA, depending on comorbidity status, but was not recommended for hip or polyarticular OA. The study did not report specific efficacy metrics for aquatic exercise.
population_specificity: Individuals with knee, hip, or polyarticular osteoarthritis.

study_goal: To determine the effect of an aquatic physical exercise program (SWEP method) during pregnancy on the rate of intact perineum after childbirth.
results_summary: Women in the aquatic exercise group had a significantly higher rate of intact perineum compared to the control group (OR = 13.54). The effect remained significant after adjusting for infant birth weight (OR = 8.57). Previous childbirth and anesthesia administration were also associated with higher odds of intact perineum.
population_specificity: 129 pregnant women in Granada, Spain (64 control, 65 aquatic exercise group).
effective_dosage: Three sessions per week of aquatic physical exercises.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of dual-task aquatic exercises on functional mobility, balance, and gait in individuals with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The dual-task aquatic exercise program significantly improved functional mobility, balance, and gait in individuals with Parkinson's disease, with sustained benefits observed at a three-month follow-up. The Experimental Group showed statistically significant improvements compared to the Control Group across all measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (n=25 analyzed, 14 in Experimental Group, 11 in Control Group).
effective_dosage: Twice a week for 40 minutes per session in a heated pool (33°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of aquatic aerobic exercises versus mat Pilates in improving pain and other symptoms in women with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: The study protocol was designed to evaluate pain reduction and other outcomes (disease impact, functional capacity, sleep quality, and overall quality of life) over 12 weeks, but results were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-60 with fibromyalgia and a pain score of 3-8 on the Visual Analogue Scale.

study_goal: To determine and compare the cardiorespiratory impact of 3 months of aquatic and robotic therapy for individuals with chronic motor incomplete spinal cord injury (CMISCI).
results_summary: Neither aquatic nor robotic treadmill therapy significantly improved peak VO2 in individuals with CMISCI after 3 months of intervention. The study did not demonstrate statistically meaningful cardiorespiratory benefits from either therapy.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic motor incomplete spinal cord injury (CMISCI), neurological level C2-T12, at least 1 year post-injury.
effective_dosage: 36 sessions, 40-45 min per session, at 65-75% heart rate reserve intensity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acceptability, experiences, and preferences of aquatic versus land-based exercise training in people with stable heart failure (HF).
results_summary: Aquatic exercise was found to be acceptable and beneficial, with motivators including a skilled workforce, tailored care, perceived health benefits, safety, and an enjoyable environment. Few barriers were identified for either aquatic or land-based programs.
population_specificity: People with stable heart failure (mean age 70 ± 11 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combined land-based and aquatic trunk exercise (LATE) program improves trunk control, balance, and activities of daily living in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The LATE group showed statistically significant improvements in trunk control, balance, and daily living activities compared to the control group, suggesting the program is effective as an adjunct to conventional therapy.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients in an inpatient rehabilitation ward.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per day, 5 days per week (combined land-based and aquatic exercises).

study_goal: To determine whether slow aquatic exercise (modified Ai Chi) is more effective than conventional aquatic therapy at reducing arm volume in women with or at risk of breast cancer-related lymphoedema.
results_summary: Modified Ai Chi showed a larger immediate reduction in arm volume (140mL) compared to conventional aquatic therapy, though the effect was not sustained at 1-hour follow-up. Satisfaction was good for both interventions, and no differences were found in bio-impedance.
population_specificity: Women with a history of breast cancer-related lymphoedema (n=18).
effective_dosage: 50-minute sessions for each intervention (modified Ai Chi and conventional aquatic therapy).
study_duration: Two intervention sessions, one week apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of aquatic exercises versus patient-education in improving pain, function, and quality of life in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise significantly improved pain and functional capacity after eight weeks, with sustained functional benefits at the three-month follow-up compared to patient-education. No significant differences were observed for functional mobility or depression outcomes.
population_specificity: 60 patients (aged 68.3 ± 4.8 years) with knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grades 1-4).
effective_dosage: 16 individual aquatic exercise sessions (twice a week) over eight weeks.
study_duration: Eight weeks, with a three-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically analyze the effectiveness of aquatic exercise in relieving pain and improving physical function in patients with low back pain.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that aquatic exercise significantly reduced pain and improved physical function in patients with low back pain, but did not show significant effects on general mental health.
population_specificity: Patients with low back pain (331 participants across 8 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the immediate ambulatory blood pressure response (postexercise hypotension) after a session of aquatic exercise in physically active, older women with hypertension.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise resulted in significantly lower systolic blood pressure (5.1 mm Hg) and diastolic blood pressure (1.2 mm Hg) over 21 hours compared to the control session, with reductions observed during both awake and sleep hours. The antihypertensive effects were comparable to those seen with land aerobic exercise.
population_specificity: Physically active older women (70.0 ± 3.9 years) with hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether balance and postural stability exercises in a spa-based rehabilitation program improved outcomes for individuals with ankylosing spondylitis (AS).
results_summary: The study group showed significant improvements in balance tests (TUG, SLST, FRT) and reductions in AS-specific measures (BASMI, BASFI, BASDAI, ASQoL). Combining balance exercises with spa-based rehabilitation enhanced physiotherapy benefits.
population_specificity: Individuals with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) experiencing functional disorders and balance loss.
effective_dosage: 5 days per week for 3 weeks (routine physiotherapy, TENS, spa and land-based exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an aquatic exercise program on improving the physical condition of patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Significant improvements were observed in the experimental group's physical condition post-intervention, with notable differences compared to the control group across all functional tests. The results align with existing literature supporting aquatic exercise for MS patients.
population_specificity: 26 participants with multiple sclerosis (13 in the experimental group, 13 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Three sessions per week, 45-60 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of peer-delivered programs, including aquatic exercise, in promoting physical activity and improving physical outcomes in older adults.
results_summary: The study included one aquatic exercise group among various interventions, but meta-analysis findings did not conclusively support peer involvement for improving physical function in older adults. Overall, peer involvement showed potential for promoting exercise adherence, but results were mixed regarding physical function improvements.
population_specificity: Older adults (average age 66.5 years, 67.1% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a supervised aquatic exercise program during pregnancy could influence maternal weight gain and birth weight.
results_summary: The study found that aquatic exercise reduced excessive maternal weight gain (24.5% in the exercise group vs. 45.2% in the control group) but did not affect birth weight or other pregnancy outcomes.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (n=111) with uncomplicated, singleton pregnancies, aged 31.6 ± 3.8 years.
effective_dosage: 3 weekly sessions of aerobic and resistance aquatic activities.
study_duration: From weeks 10-12 until weeks 38-39 of gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and efficacy of aquatic exercise training during a maintenance phase for patients with heart failure who had previously completed rehabilitation.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise was feasible for stable heart failure patients and helped maintain functional performance, though land-based training showed greater improvement in the 6-minute walk test. No significant differences were observed for grip strength, walk speed, or balance between the two protocols.
population_specificity: Patients with stable heart failure (43 males, mean age 69.2 years) who had completed prior rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Once per week for six weeks.
study_duration: 12 weeks total (6 weeks per protocol in a crossover design).

study_goal: To review the literature on the effects of aquatic intervention on gross motor skills for children with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: Most studies reported improvements in gross motor skills within group analyses after aquatic programs, but results were mixed, and evidence was limited. Only two studies used randomized control trial designs, and quality of evidence was moderate to high for only one study.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-21 years with cerebral palsy, classified as GMFCS levels I-V.
effective_dosage: Two to three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess and compare the effects of aquatic exercise programs on muscle strength and physical function in people with osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: Aquatic exercise showed beneficial effects on physical function, but only two out of five studies observed positive effects on muscle strength. Well-structured programs with controlled intensity and overload were found to be effective.
population_specificity: Individuals with osteoarthritis (OA).
effective_dosage: Exercise programs included muscle strengthening, aerobic, balance, flexibility, and stretching exercises; duration, frequency, intensity, and progression varied between studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of an aquatic exercise program on enhancing muscular strength in paretic lower limbs and improving functional outcomes in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The aquatic exercise group showed significantly higher knee extension and ankle plantarflexion torque, lower knee extension cocontraction ratios, and greater improvements in Functional Ambulation Category and Barthel Index compared to the conventional group, without increasing spasticity.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients (n=36, divided into two groups of 18 each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of aquatic resistance training on the biochemical composition of tibiofemoral cartilage and secondary outcomes like cardiorespiratory fitness in postmenopausal women with mild knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Aquatic resistance training significantly improved cartilage integrity (reduced T2 and dGEMRIC index) in the medial femoral cartilage and enhanced cardiorespiratory fitness by 9.8% compared to controls.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 60-68 with mild knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grades I/II and knee pain).
effective_dosage: 48 supervised sessions over 16 weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of aquatic exercise as an intervention to improve occupational performance for individuals with psychosocial, behavioral, or emotional impairments after traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: The study found moderate evidence supporting the use of aquatic exercise for improving occupational performance and participation in individuals with TBI-related impairments. It was grouped among interventions with moderate evidence, alongside goal-directed therapy and functional skills training.
population_specificity: Individuals with psychosocial, behavioral, or emotional impairments following traumatic brain injury (TBI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of aqua-cycling, combined with usual care, on knee pain and physical functioning in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a randomized controlled trial comparing aqua-cycling plus usual care to usual care alone, but the abstract does not provide specific results regarding the intervention's effects.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren/Lawrence score 1-3), knee pain rated 4-7/10, and no contraindications for aquatic exercise.
effective_dosage: Two 45-minute moderate-intensity aqua-cycling sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aquatic exercise, alongside standard immune regulatory medication, could reduce fatigue, depression, and paresthesia in women with MS compared to a nonexercise control.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise significantly reduced fatigue, depression, and paresthesia compared to the nonexercise control group, with a 35-fold lower likelihood of moderate to severe depression in the intervention groups.
population_specificity: 54 women with MS (mean age 33.94 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term effects of water-based exercise combined with blood flow restriction (BFR) on maximum dynamic strength and functional capacity in post-menopausal women.
results_summary: Water-based exercise with BFR significantly increased lower limb maximum strength, which was not observed with water-based exercise alone. Both water-based exercise groups (with and without BFR) improved functional performance (timed up and go test) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Post-menopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aquatic exercise on fatigue and quality of life in women with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Aquatic exercise significantly improved quality of life and reduced fatigue severity and perception in physical and psychosocial domains, but had no significant effect on cognitive fatigue perception.
population_specificity: 37 outpatient women with MS in Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of therapeutic aquatic exercise (TAE) on symptoms and function associated with lower limb osteoarthritis (OA) through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed significant improvements in pain, self-reported function, physical functioning, stiffness, and quality of life for participants engaging in TAE compared to a nontreatment control group. However, limitations included heterogeneity in outcome measures and small sample sizes in some trials.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower limb osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of aquatic exercise in managing pain, physical function, and quality of life in adults with musculoskeletal conditions compared to no exercise or land-based exercise.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise showed moderate improvements in pain, physical function, and quality of life compared to no exercise, with no significant differences observed between aquatic and land-based exercise for these outcomes. The benefits were consistent across different musculoskeletal conditions.
population_specificity: Adults with musculoskeletal conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 10 years of regular aquatic exercise could reduce the risk of all-cause death or the need for dialysis in CKD patients not yet on dialysis.
results_summary: The study found that none of the aquatic exercise group reached dialysis or died over 10 years, while 55% of the sedentary control group reached the study endpoint (renal replacement therapy or death). The difference between groups was statistically significant (P=0.037).
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients not yet on dialysis.
effective_dosage: Low-intensity aerobic aquatic exercise twice a week, with at least 32 weeks of sessions annually.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the acute effect of moderate-intensity aquatic exercise on haemostasis in adults with haemophilia.
results_summary: The study found a possibly beneficial effect on prothrombin time (PT) and trivial changes in fibrinogen levels, with unclear effects on factor VIII (FVIII) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT). Greater changes were observed in patients with moderate haemophilia, and a correlation was found between heart rate rise during exercise and PT decrement.
population_specificity: Ten adult haemophiliacs (8 type A, 2 type B) familiarized with aquatic training.
effective_dosage: 20-minute exercise session at ~70% maximum heart rate.
